title: 109_hr4007
content: Two-year eligibility for Department of Veterans Affairs health care for members of the Armed Forces serving in areas affected by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Section 1710(e) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow members of the Armed Forces responding to disasters or emergencies in areas affected by Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita to be eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care, regardless of medical evidence attributing their disability to such duty. In the case of a member of the Armed Forces described in paragraph (1)(F), hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care may not be provided if the disability is found to have resulted from a cause other than duty described in that paragraph. Additionally, care for a veteran described in paragraph (1)(F) is eligible after a period of two years from the date of discharge or release from duty described in that paragraph. The term 'area affected by Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita' is defined as an area designated for assistance by Federal Disaster Declaration notice 1602-1607 in August and September 2005. SEC. 2. Health assessment of servicemembers exposed to environmental hazards in areas affected by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. The purpose of this section is for the National Academy of Sciences to review and make recommendations for health surveillance of uniformed service members exposed to environmental hazards in areas affected by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense are required to seek an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences within 60 days to perform these activities. The National Academy of Sciences will review data on environmental exposures and health effects on uniformed service members during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. Recommendations will be made for identifying and collecting data for these members. The National Academy of Sciences will review data on environmental exposures and health effects on uniformed service members during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. Recommendations will be made for the development of a registry to monitor morbidity and mortality data for these members, including the establishment, location, and content of the registry, as well as policies for ongoing health surveillance. A report on the activities of the National Academy of Sciences under the agreement must be submitted within 180 days, along with recommendations for additional scientific studies to resolve areas of scientific uncertainty. The National Academy of Sciences will review data on environmental exposures and health effects on uniformed service members during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. Recommendations will be made for the development of a registry to monitor morbidity and mortality data for these members. If an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences cannot be reached, the Secretaries will seek another scientific organization for the same purposes. If the Secretaries cannot reach an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences, they will seek another organization with expertise and objectivity for monitoring health data of uniformed service members affected by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. Any reference to the National Academy of Sciences in this section will then refer to the new organization. Annual report on health care for hurricane-affected National Guard members by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will maintain a database of Armed Forces members receiving healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. An annual report must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of veterans seeking treatment at VA facilities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will report the number of veterans receiving healthcare under section 1710(e)(1)(F) of title 38, United States Code, including costs for eligible and ineligible veterans.
